candidates.title: Jaden Smith Commits Suicide
candidates.content:
Claim:
Actor Jaden Smith committed suicide in July 2016.
Rating:
False
About this rating
In July 2016, news raced through social media that Jaden Smith, actor and son of Will and Jada Pinkett-Smith, had committed suicide:
The news was not true, and didn't come from a legitimate source. In fact, users who clicked the above-displayed message were greeted with a popup message requesting permission from a Facebook app to post on their behalf, making the article appear less like a hoax and more like an outright scam:
Messages about Jaden Smith's alleged suicide were shared from various sites, and led to a variety of dodgy-sounding Facebook apps, including "Smart Mobiles," "Gadgy Land," "Pakiza," "Top Feeds" and several others.
Intrepid internet users who clicked the link and gave the app permission were eventually greeted with one of several "news" story claiming that Jaden Smith had committed suicide. The web sites responsible for this hoax have published dozens of fake news stories and graphics with this false claim:
Users who granted these apps permission to post to Facebook on their behalf quickly found this death hoax posted to their own Facebook feeds, thereby replicating itself across social media.
Jaden Smith himself has been active on his social media accounts, seemingly unaware that he's supposed to be dead. He posted a photograph of himself on 27 July 2016:
candidates.description: A hoax article reported that the actor (and teenaged son of Jada Pinkett Smith and Will Smith) had killed himself.

result.explanation: The news caption stating that actor Jaden Smith committed suicide in July 2016 is decisively contradicted by the retrieved related articles, particularly those from Snopes, which unequivocally label this claim as false. The article outlines a considerable misinformation campaign that circulated this rumor through social media channels, characterizing it as a well-known death hoax rather than an actual event. Notably, the articles describe how users were misled by a fake article that falsely reported Smith’s suicide. These reports gained traction on platforms such as Facebook, often inviting engagement through dubious applications, which further propagated the hoax across social media. This misleading narrative was reinforced by the fact that Jaden Smith himself was active on social media during and after the purported time of his death, including posting a picture of himself on July 27, 2016, which illustrates that he was very much alive. Additionally, the framing of the information as a hoax from a fact-checking domain (Snopes) profoundly impacts its reliability, placing it in stark contradiction to the news caption's assertion. Overall, the claims of Jaden Smith’s suicide are not supported—they are debunked with clear evidence collected at the time and afterward. The credibility of the sources reporting the event, particularly the fact-checking nature of Snopes.com, suggests that there is no legitimacy to the claim made in the caption. Thus, the caption is rated false due to its direct inconsistency with established factual reporting from reliable sources regarding Jaden Smith's status in July 2016.
